newsitem.title: COLOMBIA: Colombian stocks end lower, weighed down by cement.
newsitem.headline: Colombian stocks end lower, weighed down by cement.

text.p: Colombian stocks ended slightly lower as investor concerns about local cement makers losing market share to Mexico's Cemex weighed down equities for the second consecutive day.
The losses were limited, however, with Medellin's IBOMED general price index ending down just 0.15 percent at 13,129.52 and Bogota's IBB inching down a miniscule 0.06 percent to close at 847.21.
More than 1.5 billion pesos of shares traded hands in Bogota, while volume in Medellin totalled 1.2 billion.

As in Thursday's trading, the day's biggest losers were cement companies. Brokers said selling was prompted by investor fears that Cemex, the world's third-largest cement company, positioned itself to become a dominant player in the Colombian market with the purchase of Industrias e Inversiones Samper earlier this week.
Cemex had already purchased Cementos Diamante earlier this year and its total $700 million investment in Colombia is expected to result in fierce market competition.
Diamante was among the stocks most hurt by Friday's liquidation of cement stocks.
The company, which Cemex purchased in May, fell 4.76 percent in Medellin to close at 3,800 pesos per share. It closed down 2.56 percent in Bogota, also ending at 3,800.
Cementos Argos, another leading cement company, fell 1.90 percent in Bogota, ending the session at 5,160 pesos per share.

Other losers included insurance giant Suramericana de Seguros, which ended down 2.77 percent at 3,800 pesos a share and Banco de Colombia, which slipped 2.29 percent in Medellin to end at 425 pesos a share.
